docs.lead_paragraph: Pierre Lewandoski lay still as Évian mineral water, heated to 95 degrees, bubbled and swirled, gently massaging his middle-aged body. Dressed in a small, fitted swimsuit in shades of ocean blue, Mr. Lewandoski, a car mechanic from Arras in northern France, seemed eager to explain what he was doing in a bathtub on the banks of Lake Geneva 500 miles from home.

headline.main: Évian Offers Its Magic By Tubful

docs.abstract: Evian, France, with its lucrative mineral water and spas, profiled in light of upcoming summit meeting there of world's eight major industrialized nations; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A bipartisan team of governors appeared to make progress this week toward agreement on a comprehensive plan to revamp Medicaid. But powerful Democrats in Congress immediately urged Democratic governors to reject the deal, saying it would hurt poor people. Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa, a Democrat, said tonight: ''We've made some progress. There's quite a ways to go.''

headline.main: Governors Cite Progress on a Medicaid Plan

docs.abstract: Bipartisan team of governors makes progress toward agreement on comprehensive plan to revamp Medicaid, which provides health coverage to 50 million low income people, and is financed by federal government and states; Democrats in Congress have urged Democratic governors to reject plan, saying it would hurt poor people; proposal is for states to accept some limits on growth of federal Medicaid spending in return for sweeping new power to alter benefits and eligibility; critics say allotments are block grants and could be diverted to cover unexpected costs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A bipartisan team of governors appeared to make progress this week toward agreement on a comprehensive plan to revamp Medicaid. But powerful Democrats in Congress immediately urged Democratic governors to reject the deal, saying it would hurt poor...

docs.lead_paragraph: In more prosperous times just a few years ago, Kiwako Kaiyama and Kiyoko Kitamura looked to a future of kicking back on their husbands' salaries. Instead, to make ends meet, the 40-something housewives have had to cut their spending, take part-time jobs and -- shockingly, for Japan -- dip into their savings. For decades, the Japanese routinely socked away 10 to 20 percent of their incomes, earning a reputation as one of the world's most frugal people. In those years, Japan badgered the United States about its wasteful ways and trade deficits, even as Japanese companies benefited from selling Americans cars and electronics.
docs.abstract: Japanese, long known for frugality and saving, feel effects of decade of recession and find they are dipping into savings to make ends meet; rapidly aging society is partly responsible, as fewer workers are paying taxes and, by 2010, more than 22 percent of population will be at least 65 years old; Japan is already most heavily indebted nation in developed world; working families, suffering from economic stagnation and deflation, are saving less; photo; graph shows household savings rate; chart of savings of various age groups (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In its best years, it was a pearl on the prairie, a place where bold ideas sprouted like cornstalks under the Midwestern sun, a name that meant the best that American psychiatry had to offer. Troubled souls traveled long distances to find treatment and refuge beneath the pine trees on its grounds. Generations of healers trained in its classrooms. At 10 minutes to 4 each day -- a time dictated by the 50-minute psychoanalytic hour -- the staff gathered for tea and cookies in the clinic building, chatting with visitors like Margaret Mead, Aldous Huxley and Helen Keller, drawn by its intellectual aura.

headline.main: Famed Psychiatric Clinic Abandons Prairie Home

docs.abstract: Menninger Clinic, Topeka, Kansas, famed psychiatric clinic that opened its doors 78 years ago, is moving to Houston, Texas, in new partnership with Baylor College of Medicine and Methodist Hospital; move marks end of era of elite private hospitals that catered to wealthy, often in bucolic settings, where patients spent months or years sorting out their lives; move leaves only one intensive long-term psychoanalytic treatment facility, Austen Riggs Center in Stockbridge, Mass; closing is attributed to change in health care economics and rise of managed care, as well as fundamental changes in psychiatry, precipitated by new drugs, brief psychotherapies and advances in neuroscience; rise and decline of clinic also reflects dynamics of family who founded it, Dr Charles Menninger and his sons, Karl and William, both doctors; debate in psychiatric community over transition discussed; clinic helped build Topeka's reputation as destination for brightest minds in field; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: If the labor movement is to have a future, if it is not to shrink to insignificance, it must unionize workers like Cristina Gomez. After 13 years as a clothing sorter for the Cintas Corporation, the nation's largest uniform rental company, Ms. Gomez earns $17,000. It is too little, she says, to buy coverage for her two daughters under the company's health insurance plan, and too little to afford anything better than her small home 40 yards from railroad tracks.

headline.main: Labor Turns to a Pivotal Organizing Drive

docs.abstract: Organized labor is trying unionize 17,000 workers at Cintas Corp, nation's largest uniform rental company; drive, conducted by Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, will not be easy, as Cintas is aggressively battling effort and workers are divided on unionization; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Documents released yesterday in the case of a drug company whistle-blower shed light on how extensively doctors were involved in promoting unapproved uses of a Warner-Lambert drug, Neurontin. Warner-Lambert paid dozens of doctors tens of thousands of dollars each to speak to other physicians about how Neurontin, an epilepsy drug, could be prescribed for more than a dozen other medical uses that had not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The top speaker for Neurontin, Dr. B. J. Wilder, a former professor of neurology at the University of Florida, received more than $300,000 for speeches given from 1994 to 1997, according to a court filing. Six other doctors, including some from top medical schools, received more than $100,000 each.

headline.main: Court Papers Suggest Scale Of Drug's Use

docs.abstract: Documents released in case of Warner-Lambert whistle-blower Dr David P Franklin shed light on how extensively doctors were involved in promoting unapproved uses of company's drug Neurontin; Warner-Lambert paid dozens of doctors tens of thousands of dollars each to speak to other physicians about how Neurontin, epilepsy drug, could be prescribed for more than dozen other medical uses that had not been approved by Food and Drug Administration; Dr B J Wilder, top speaker for Neurontin, received more than $300,000 for speeches given from 1994 to 1997; six other doctors, including some from top medical schools, received more than $100,000 each; Franklin contends company's marketing tactics were illegal; says federal and state governments paid hundreds of millions of dollars for Neurontin as doctors prescribed drug to Medicaid patients for various conditions; Pfizer acquired Warner-Lambert in 2000 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Richard L. Dombroff, a Long Island plastic surgeon with a clinic on Park Avenue, served two months in prison after acknowledging that he had allowed unlicensed people to perform procedures and had committed insurance fraud, it was a classic case of a hard fall from the top. More than 15 years later, Mr. Dombroff has fallen even harder. After a six-month trial, a Suffolk County jury convicted him on Wednesday of grand larceny and scheming to defraud in connection with a loan business he started several years after his release from prison, by which point he had given up his medical license. (The judge in the latest trial allowed him to be referred to as ''Doctor,'' his lawyers said.)

headline.main: For a Former Plastic Surgeon, Loan Fraud Is Latest Trouble

docs.abstract: Suffolk County, NY, jury convicts former plastic surgeon Richard Dombroff of grand larcency and scheming to defraud in connection with loan business for medical insurance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Harvard dismissed Timothy Leary, the psychology professor turned psychedelic drug guru, in 1963, he dropped out, at the invitation of a wealthy benefactor, to Millbrook. This polished enclave of vast estates and hundred-acre horse farms set in the lush hills of the eastern Hudson River Valley became the unlikely home of Leary's Castalia Institute, where he conducted controversial experiments with LSD. (It is also where he was arrested by G. Gordon Liddy, then with the Dutchess County Sheriff's Department, in one of several brushes with the law.) The Castalia Institute no longer exists and these days Millbrook has a different kind of research center, the Institute of Ecosystem Studies, with a director, Gene Liken, who studies a different kind of acid: acid rain. Many weekend residents are patrons. ''It's an oasis,'' said Ronald S. Gross, a corporate lawyer with a Ph.D. in botany who has an apartment in Manhattan and a house in Millbrook. ''We listen to top scientists lecture on significant issues like Lyme disease.''
docs.abstract: Article on Millbrook, NY, as place to live and visit; photo; map; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Miami gave Aetna preliminary approval yesterday for a $170 million plan to settle assertions by 700,000 doctors that the company unfairly cut reimbursements. The settlement approved by Judge Federico Moreno of United States District Court gives physicians $100 million. Aetna, which is based in Hartford, also agreed to pay $20 million to create a foundation to address health care problems and $50 million in legal costs.

headline.main: Aetna Settlement With Doctors Wins Approval of Federal Judge

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Federico Moreno gives Aetna preliminary approval for $170 million plan to settle assertions by 700,000 doctors that company unfairly cut reimbursements (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The world outside the Himalaya Mountains ''discovered'' Mount Everest in the 19th century. Since then, foreigners have sought to conquer, market and control it. Though Sherpas and their Tibetan kin had known Everest -- or Chomolungma -- for centuries, not one of them wanted to climb it until my grandfather, Tenzing Norgay, came along. He made it to the summit, with Sir Edmund Hillary, 50 years ago today -- and life for Sherpas has never been the same. My grandfather's dream to climb Everest was unusual for someone of his background. Sherpas once believed that the great summits were the dwelling places of Buddhist spirits and must not be violated. But even as a young lad in Nepal, my grandfather wondered whether it would be possible to make it to the top of Everest. His family made good-humored fun of his talk. In 1935, however, they were compelled to take him seriously. That year, he joined the Everest expedition of the British climber Eric Shipton, which made it to the Northeast Ridge -- close, but still about half a mile away.
docs.abstract: Tashi Tenzing Op-Ed article holds life has not been same for Nepal's Sherpas since his grandfather, Tenzing Norgay, climbed Mount Everest with Sir Edmund Hillary 50 years ago; notes Everest mountaineering has become popular sport and booming business, raising standard of living for Sherpas while leading many to seek easier, more cosmopolitan existence in cities and abroad; drawing (M)
